page.title: 01The slopes of Olrig Hill
page.content: The area is bounded on the north side by its highest point, Olrig hill on which the vegetation is grass, moss and gorse used for sheep grazing. Descending the hill to the east, west and south the ground becomes more intensively cultivated, largely for grazing and silage, with small areas of (recent) coniferous forest. The area is divided by traditional local quarried dry-stone and flagstone walls, large and irregular areas on the high ground and smaller more regular and often wire fenced fields on the lower ground. The farming is mainly sheep with some dairy and beef and the area contains some 30 or so dwellings, mostly farms. On Olrig hill is the main telecommunications radio link station and to the east of this is the edge of the Olrig house estate with its old deciduous wood.
